raw_text:
Italy 8-38 Wales
 
 Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory in Rome.
 
 Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams gave the visitors a 19-5 half-time advantage. Luciano Orquera did reply with one for Italy but second-half efforts from Brent Cockbain, Shane Williams and Robert Sidoli sealed victory. Fly-half Stephen Jones added four conversions as Wales maintained their superb start to this year's tournament. Starting full of confidence after their victory over England, the visitors scored the opening try after just four minutes. Diminutive wing Shane Williams fielded a kick ahead and danced past the onrushing Andrea Masi and Aaron Persico into the Italian half. His pass to Tom Shanklin appeared forward but when the centre was held up short, the ball was switched left and Michael Owen's long cut-out pass gave the lurking Thomas an easy run-in.
 
 Stephen Jones, who retained the kicking duties despite Gavin Henson's heroics against England, slotted an excellent conversion from wide out. Wales twice threatened further scores but failed to find the crucial pass, and Italy hit back out of the blue in the 11th minute.
 
 Henson, sporting gold boots rather than the silver variety that did for England, beat two players with ease out on the left touchline. But his attempted chip ahead was charged down by Orquera, who snaffled the loose ball and hared away from halfway to score in the right corner. With the Welsh line-out stuttering and Italy twice turning the visitors' scrum, the home side's forward power brought them back into it. But a clever high kick from Henson almost brought a try for Hal Luscombe when Roland de Marigny and Ludovico Nitoglia made a hash of claiming it as the ball bounced into touch.
 
 Wales regained control with a second try in the 21st minute, Henson lobbing up a high kick to the left corner where Shanklin jumped higher than Nitoglia to dot down his 15th Test try. Jones was unable to convert and De Marigny then hit the upright with a penalty attempt for Italy. Henson was also narrowly short with a long-range effort at goal, but Wales ended the half with a vital third score to give themselves some breathing space.
 
 Henson sent Luscombe streaking away and when he off-loaded to Martyn Williams, the flanker showed his nous to ground the ball against the padding of the post, Jones adding the conversion. Italy, who lost flanker Mauro Bergamasco with a head knock before half-time, built up a head of steam on the resumption. De Marigny landed a penalty to make it 19-8 and a Nitoglia break through the middle threatened a try only for the move to break down with a knock-on. But Wales put the outcome beyond doubt with two superb tries in four minutes before the hour. Their fourth after 53 minutes was sparked by another mazy run from Shane Williams, who beat several players with ease, and finished with a powerful angled run from lock Cockbain. Before Italy could recover from that blow, a strong surge from Gareth Thomas and great off-loads from Martyn Williams and replacement Kevin Morgan saw Shane Williams scamper over.
 
 With Jones converting both for a 33-8 lead, Wales had the luxury of sending on five more replacements for the final quarter. The icing on the cake came with a sixth try after more superb support work, Shane Williams and Ceri Sweeney combining to send Sidoli over in the left corner. The only downside for Wales was a hamstring injury suffered by Luscombe. But after back-to-back wins at the start of the tournament for the first time in 11 years, they will travel to Paris in a fortnight looking like genuine contenders.
 
 R de Marigny; Mirco Bergamasco, W Pozzebon, A Masi, L Nitoglia; L Orquera, A Troncon; A Lo Cicero, F Ongaro, M Castrogiovanni, S Dellape, M Bortolami (capt), A Persico, Mauro Bergamasco, S Parisse.
 
 G Intoppa, S Perugini, CA del Fava, D dal Maso, P Griffen, M Barbini, KP Robertson.
 
 G Thomas (capt); H Luscombe, T Shanklin, G Henson, S Williams; S Jones, D Peel; G Jenkins, M Davies, A Jones; B Cockbain, R Sidoli; J Thomas, M Williams, M Owen.
 
 R McBryde, J Yapp, I Gough, R Sowden-Taylor, G Cooper, C Sweeney, K Morgan.
 
 Andrew Cole (Australia).
llama3.2:1b:
Italy 8-38 Wales
Wales secured a six-try victory in Rome with Jonathan Thomas scoring tries and Stephen Jones adding conversions. The visitors scored four first-half tries before halftime, while Italy responded with two. In the second half, Shane Williams' mazy run led to three more Welsh tries, including one from Gareth Thomas that sealed the win.
llama3.2:3b: Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a 6-try victory over Italy. Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams gave Wales a 19-5 lead at halftime. Italy responded but Wales regained control with two more tries before halftime. The visitors maintained their lead throughout the second half, scoring five more tries to seal a 33-8 win.
gemma2:2b: Wales won against Italy 8-38 in Rome. Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams scored tries for Wales, while Luciano Orquera and Brent Cockbain scored for Italy.  Stephen Jones converted a number of tries for Wales, including a successful conversion after Shane Williams's try just before the half time break. The match saw multiple scoring opportunities from both sides, with Italy making a comeback in the second half and eventually conceding defeat.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Wales secured their first away win in the Six Nations by defeating Italy 8-38. The visitors, led by a six-try performance from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, Martyn Williams, Luciano Orquera, Brent Cockbain, and Shane Williams, maintained their superb start to the tournament with a total of 19 tries. Wales' key players were Stephen Jones, Tom Shanklin, and Shane Williams providing crucial scoring chances. The game was marked by a strong opening half where Wales scored quickly after just four minutes from a try by Tom Shanklin. The visitors secured a late bonus point when Luscombe converted, but Welsh power continued to move the game.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Wales secured a 38-19 win over Italy in Rome, building a half-time lead of 19-5. Wales scored three times after halftime and converted two of those tries. Despite Italy regaining some momentum in the second half with penalties, Wales maintained their strong start to the tournament, winning their first away game since 2016.
qwen2.5:3b:
Italy 8-38 Wales:
Wales won their first away Six Nations match in nearly four years, scoring six tries to Italy's one. The victory came after a strong start with Shane Williams opening the scoring and Tom Shanklin adding a second try. A late surge by Wales saw wing Shane Williams score two more tries, followed by a third from replacement Kevin Morgan. Martyn Williams and Gareth Thomas both scored further tries for Wales, while Steven Jones kicked 4 conversions. Italy responded with one try from Luciano Orquera but could not stop the flood of scores as Wales maintained their strong start to the tournament.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so the user has given me this text about a football match between Italy and Wales. They want me to summarize it concisely, focusing on key ideas and details. The output should be plain text without any explanations or formatting.

First, I'll read through the entire text carefully to identify the main points. It starts with the match result: Italy 8-38 Wales. Then, it goes into details about how Wales secured their win in Rome, with six tries by Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams. Italy replied with one try but couldn't get much from the second half.

I notice that the summary should include both the scoreline and significant events during the match. I'll mention the team's confidence, the early goals, and how Wales maintained their strong start despite losing some games earlier in the tournament.

Also, there are substitutions mentioned, which is important to note for completeness. The team's line-out issue at the end adds depth. I should include that as a key point since it affects the outcome.

I'll structure this into two paragraphs: one for the summary with score and highlights, another for the substitution list. That way, both elements are clear and easy to follow.
</think>

Italy 8-38 Wales  
Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory in Rome. Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams gave the visitors a 19-5 half-time advantage. Luciano Orquera replied with one try but second-half efforts from Brent Cockbain, Shane Williams, and Robert Sidoli sealed victory. Fly-half Stephen Jones added four conversions as Wales maintained their superb start to this year's tournament. Tensions for Wales were high early in the game, with starting full confidence after their Rome victory but losing some games earlier in the tournament. Despite a line-out issue at the end, Wales regrouped and secured another try before the hour.  

Wales regained control with a second try in the 21st minute, Henson lobbing up a high kick to the left corner where Shanklin jumped higher than Nitoglia to dot down his 15th Test try. Jones was unable to convert but De Marigny then hit the upright with a penalty attempt for Italy. Henson was narrowly short with a long-range effort at goal, but Wales ended the half with a vital third score to give themselves some breathing space.  

Henson sent Luscombe streaking away and when he off-loaded to Martyn Williams, the flanker showed his nous to ground the ball against the padding of the post, Jones adding the conversion. Italy, who lost flanker Mauro Bergamasco with a head knock before half-time, built up a head of steam on the resumption. De Marigny landed a penalty to make it 19-8 and a Nitoglia break through the middle threatened a try only for the move to break down with a knock-on. But Wales put the outcome beyond doubt with two superb tries in four minutes before the hour. Their fourth after 53 minutes was sparked by another mazy run from Shane Williams, who beat several players with ease, and finished with a powerful angled run from lock Cockbain.  

Before Italy could recover from that blow, a strong surge from Gareth Thomas and great off-loads from Martyn Williams and replacement Kevin Morgan saw Shane Williams scamper over. With Jones converting both for a 33-8 lead, Wales had the luxury of sending on five more replacements for the final quarter. The icing on the cake came with a sixth try after more superb support work, Shane Williams and Ceri Sweeney combining to send Sidoli over in the left corner.  

The only downside for Wales was a hamstring injury suffered by Luscombe. But after back-to-back wins at the start of the tournament for the first time in 11 years, they will travel to Paris in a fortnight looking like genuine contenders.
tinyllama:1.1b: Italy secured their first away win in the Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory against Wales. The visitors scored the opening try after just four minutes and added another three tries in the second half as well as converting one conversion, all from wide out, to secure the win. Stephen Jones retained the kicking duties despite Gavin Henson's heroics against England but Italy hit back with two strong supports to score a fourth try before Wales sent on five more replacements for the final quarter. The only downside was a hamstring injury suffered by Luscombe, but Wales were confident going into Paris in a fortnight looking like genuine contenders.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In the Six Nations rugby match between Wales and Italy, Wales secured their first away win in the tournament with a 33-8 victory at the Allianz Stadium in Rome. The win marked the beginning of an unbeaten streak for the Welsh team and helped them maintain their strong start to this year's tournament. In the match, key players such as Gareth Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams led the way for Wales while Italy was managed by a combination of players including Jonathan Thomas and Tom Shanklin. The final score showed Wales with an 8-3 lead after the first half of play. However, in the second half of the match, a strong push from Italy's players resulted in a 19-5 advantage for their team, which was later equalized by a try from Wales's Gareth Williams. With time running out, Shane Williams scored the final tries for his team to secure the victory. The win was important for both teams as they look to maintain their momentum going into their upcoming match against France in Paris in a fortnight.
phi:2.7b:
Italy suffered their first away loss to Wales in nearly four years, losing 19-5 in the second half of a Six Nations match. The game started with a try for Wales' Martyn Williams from a kick-off and followed by two more tries for Wales—one converted by Gareth Thomas, a fly-half, and one for Michael Owen, a winger. In contrast, Italy scored only once during the match, in the second half, to level the score at 19-5 after Wales's first try. From then on, Italy struggled to find an opening, with both teams struggling to convert tries into points. However, Italy managed to secure two penalties and a conversion from Stephen Jones, the fly-half for the Italian team.
 
The game remained one-sided until a late try by Shane Williams put Wales back in the lead. It was after this point that Italy started to show their class, with a few excellent plays and a powerful kick from Gareth Thomas putting them in front again. However, it wasn't long before Wales took control of the game once more, scoring three tries in four minutes—one each by Shane Williams, Martyn Williams, and Michael Owen. The last try was scored just after half-time when Stephen Jones kicked the ball into the back of the net from a scrum, followed by two conversions.
 
Italy's only chance to score again came during a break caused by an injury to Gareth Thomas, but they were not able to make any ground. In the final minutes of the game, Wales tried one last time to extend their lead with a try from Martyn Williams. However, Italy was too strong at this point and secured the win for themselves with two tries in four minutes—one from a penalty kick and the other from a fly-half kick into touch.
 
The victory allowed Italy to join Wales as one of the top teams in the Six Nations tournament. Both teams will now be looking forward to their next match, which will be played in Paris in just two weeks' time.
orca-mini:3b: Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory in Rome. Italy started well but Wales built up a head of steam and secured their fourth try through Martyn Williams before the hour. Gareth Thomas and Ceri Sweeney combined to see Shane Williams score and the final score of 33-8 was confirmed with a sixth try from Rugby Steve Sidoli. Despite a hamstring injury suffered by hooker Luscombe, Wales continued to dominate and looked like genuine contenders with back-to-back wins at the start of the tournament for the first time in 11 years.

Wales score opening try after 4 minutes and maintain lead throughout the game; Italy scores one try but fails to challenge significantly. Wales' Tries: J Thomas, T Shanklin, M Williams, B Cockbain, S Williams (x2), R Sidoli.

Stephen Jones added four conversions as Wales achieved a 33-8 lead and ultimately secured the win. This victory marked Wales' first back-to-back wins at the beginning of the tournament in 11 years.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Wales secured their first away win in the 2013 RBS Six Nations tournament with a dominant 8-38 victory over Italy in Rome. Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, Martyn Williams, and Brent Cockbain in the second half sealed the win. Fly-half Stephen Jones added four conversions, contributing significantly to Wales' triumph. The match started with Wales scoring early, thanks to a try by Shane Williams after receiving a well-executed pass from Gavin Henson. Italy responded with a try of their own, following a charged-down kick by Henson.

Wales maintained control, adding two more tries before halftime, with Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams scoring. After the break, they scored twice in quick succession, demonstrating their dominance. Ceri Sidoli and Brent Cockbain crossed the try line for Wales, who ended the game with five substitutions. The match marked Wales' first back-to-back victories since 2003. Italy's Mauro Bergamasco was injured in the first half, and they finished with 11 men after a knock-on by Roland de Marigny.
